title: 108_s851
content: The "Child Custody Protection Act" may be cited as the short title. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new chapter on the transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion. The "Child Custody Protection Act" introduces a new chapter in Title 18, United States Code, regarding the transportation of minors across state lines for abortions, in violation of parental involvement laws. Offenders face fines or imprisonment for abridging parental rights. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits minors from being transported across state lines for abortions without parental consent, except in cases where the minor's life is in danger due to a physical disorder or illness. Offenders may face fines or imprisonment for violating parental rights. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits minors from being transported across state lines for abortions without parental consent. Parents cannot be prosecuted for violations of this section, and there is an affirmative defense if the defendant reasonably believed parental consent was obtained. Parents can seek relief in a civil action for harm suffered from violations. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits minors from being transported across state lines for abortions without parental consent. Parents can seek relief in a civil action for harm suffered from violations. The term 'parent' in the context of the "Child Custody Protection Act" refers to a parent, guardian, legal custodian, or a person standing in loco parentis who has care and control of the minor. The term 'minor' refers to an individual who is not older than the maximum age requiring parental notification or consent for abortion decisions. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia. The "Child Custody Protection Act" requires parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia and other territories of the United States. "117A.
